page_content='H7821-0117 (Gange Burial Ground): Consent to Excavate C1005, February 2016 

23 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
\x0c3  ARCHAEOLOGICAL INVESTIGATION 

The archaeological investigations  conducted at H7821-0117 (Gange Burial Ground) were carried out 
to  satisfy  the  following  conditions  of  Heritage  Victoria  Consent  C1005  (Appendix  1).  The  project 
methodology comprised two stages, commencing with monitored mechanical surface clearance to a 
maximum  depth  of  500  mm,  followed  by  manual  excavation  to  evaluate  any  potentially  significant 
historical archaeological features or deposits.  

3.1  Site Description  

Site H7821-0117 (Gange Burial Ground) is located at 9A Gange Place, Drysdale, Victoria (Figure 1). The 
registered site area covers an area of approximately 51 x 41 m and includes all the land  within  the 
allotment boundary.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5204_GangeBurialGround_H7821-0117.pdf'}

page_content='Victorian  Heritage  Inventory  (VHI)  site  H7821-0117  (Gange  Burial  Ground)  is  located  at  9A  Gange  Place, 
Drysdale, and covers an area of approximately 51 x 41 m (Map 1). Consent C1005 included the methodology 
for the excavation of the site that must be implemented prior to any impact works proceeding. Condition (9) 
stipulated  that  the  results  of  the  excavation  must  be  detailed  in  a  report  and  submitted  to  HV  within  12 
months of the completion of fieldwork. This report fulfils that requirement.  

Consent to Excavate 

The  archaeological  investigations  conducted  at  H7821-0117  (Gange  Burial  Ground)  were  carried  out  to 
satisfy the following conditions of Heritage Victoria Consent C1005 (Appendix 1):' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5204_GangeBurialGround_H7821-0117.pdf'}

Place, Drysdale, and covers an area of approximately 51 x 41 m (Map 1). Consent C1005 included the 
methodology  for  the  excavation  of  the  site  that  must  be  implemented  prior  to  any  impact  works 
proceeding. Condition  (9) stipulated  that the results of the excavation  must be detailed  in  a report 
and  submitted  to  HV  within  12  months  of  the  completion  of  fieldwork.  This  report  fulfils  that 
requirement.  

This report was prepared by Alison O’Connor (Senior Historical Archaeologist). The quality assurance 
review  was  undertaken  by  Oona  Nicolson  (Director/Principal  Heritage  Advisor).  The  field  work  was 
undertaken  by  Alison  O’Connor  and  Rick  Bullers  (Senior  Archaeologists  and  Heritage  Advisors). 
Mapping was provided by Monique Elsley (GIS Coordinator).

page_content='The  archaeological  investigations  conducted  at  H7821-0117  (Gange  Burial  Ground)  were  carried  out  to 
satisfy the following conditions of Heritage Victoria Consent C1005 (Appendix 1): 

1.  The project investigation must be conducted in two stages, commencing with monitored mechanical 
surface clearance to a maximum depth of 500 mm, followed by manual excavation to evaluate any 
potentially significant historical archaeological features or deposits (Condition 6). 

2.  This Consent does not authorise any disturbance to human remains (Condition 7). 

Historical Context' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5204_GangeBurialGround_H7821-0117.pdf'}

55 

 
 
 
 
 
\x0cA3.3. Scientific Significance 

Scientific significance of a heritage place (particularly archaeological sites) is also assessed in Victoria 
using a commonly accepted formula developed by Bowdler (1981) and Sullivan and Bowdler (1984). 
These are relative estimates of significance based on  the current knowledge available about sites or 
places 
in  a  region.  The  assessment  uses  three  criteria;  site  contents,  site  condition  and 
representativeness.  

Site Contents Rating 

1 

2 

3 

No cultural materials remaining. 

Site  contains  a  small  number  (e.g.  0-10  artefacts)  or  limited  range  of  cultural 
materials with no evident stratification. 

Site contains: 
a. A larger number, bit limited range of cultural materials; and/or 

b. Some intact stratified deposit. 

4 

Site contains: 

a. A large number and diverse range of cultural materials: and/or' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5204_GangeBurialGround_H7821-0117.pdf'}

page_content='I am writing to confirm the outcome of our discussion on November 26 regarding the Gange 
monument. 
As evidenced on documents supplied to this Department there are bodies buried in the 
vicinity of the known monument.25

\x0c3  ARCHAEOLOGICAL INVESTIGATION 

The archaeological investigations  conducted at H7821-0117 (Gange Burial Ground) were carried out 
to  satisfy  the  following  conditions  of  Heritage  Victoria  Consent  C1005  (Appendix  1).  The  project 
methodology comprised two stages, commencing with monitored mechanical surface clearance to a 
maximum  depth  of  500  mm,  followed  by  manual  excavation  to  evaluate  any  potentially  significant 
historical archaeological features or deposits.  

3.1  Site Description  

Site H7821-0117 (Gange Burial Ground) is located at 9A Gange Place, Drysdale, Victoria (Figure 1). The 
registered site area covers an area of approximately 51 x 41 m and includes all the land  within  the 
allotment boundary.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5204_GangeBurialGround_H7821-0117.pdf'}

page_content='  The Gange Burial Ground being the only known private 19th century family cemetery on a 

contextually substantial plot on a former rural homestead site in the City of Greater 
Geelong. The Gange Burial Ground is also a rare surviving example of a private family 
burial ground in Victoria. 

  The original burial ground allotment size and configuration being reduced from that 

historically set aside for this purpose. 

  The open, grassed setting of the place being diminished as a consequence of a reduction 

in the existing historic size. 

  Potential physical impacts and ground disturbance associated with any development on the 
site. Advice from the Senior Archaeologist at Heritage Victoria is that Ground Penetrating 
Radar and other remote sensing devices should not be relied upon (as helpful as they may 
be). Targeted archaeological testing would be required to provide certainty about the 
location and extent of the Gange burials.' metadata={'source': '/home/unimelb.edu.au/hamzeie/Desktop/hv_hackathon/data/5204_GangeBurialGround_H7821-0117.pdf'}
